unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi reported a spike in neurology cases post-Diwali, mainly due to firecracker-related injuries and increased pollution levels. Dr. Rajesh Kumar, Head of Neurology, mentioned a 25% rise in patients complaining of headaches, migraines, and even seizures. Several cases involved children exposed to excessive noise and fumes.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi reported a spike in neurology cases post-Diwali, mainly due to firecracker-related injuries and increased pollution levels. Doctor Rajesh Kumar, Head of Neurology, mentioned a twenty five percent rise in patients complaining of headaches, migraines, and even seizures. Several cases involved children exposed to excessive noise and fumes.

unnormalised: "We've seen a worrying trend," Dr. Kumar stated. "The combination of festive overindulgence, increased stress, and severe air pollution is taking a toll on the neurological health of Delhiites." He advised people to limit exposure to pollutants, stay hydrated, and manage stress levels during and after festivals.

unnormalised: One particularly concerning case involved a 10-yr-old boy, Rohan Sharma, who developed a seizure after prolonged exposure to firecracker smoke. He was immediately rushed to AIIMS and is currently under observation. Doctors suspect the chemicals in the smoke triggered the episode.

unnormalised: The neurology dept at Max Hospital, Gurgaon, also reported similar cases. Dr. Meera Patel highlighted the importance of wearing masks and using air purifiers to mitigate the effects of air pollution on the brain. "Long-term exposure can lead to cognitive decline and increase the risk of neurodegenerative diseases," she warned.

unnormalised: The Indian Medical Association (IMA) has issued an advisory urging people with pre-existing neurological conditions to take extra precautions during the festive season. They recommend keeping emergency medications readily available and avoiding crowded areas. The advisory also suggests consulting a neurologist if any unusual symptoms arise.
